title: Joe Root England Test captain: Takes over from Alastair Cook, Ben Stokes vice-captain
text:
Share on Twitter 
JOE Root has been charged with the task of leading England’s bid to retain the Ashes later this year, after the ECB confirmed the star batsman’s appointment as Test captain. 
The 26-year-old was announced as his country’s 80th skipper on Monday, taking the reins from Alastair Cook, who stood down after a record 59 Tests in charge. 
Ben Stokes will take over the role of vice-captain. 
ECB Chairman Colin Graves said Root was “the perfect choice for England Test captain”. 
“I’m delighted that he has accepted the role and will now help to take the team to the next level,” Graves said. 
“When I spoke to him last night you could feel the excitement and sense the pride — he can’t wait to get started. 
“Joe is a fine player and a fine person who has the respect of the players, the selectors and all at the ECB. He also has a changing room with experienced players and leaders who will support him from the start. 
“The role of Test captain is an honour and a responsibility which he thoroughly deserves. Joe has maturity beyond his years and having seen him develop at Yorkshire over the last ten years I know his qualities well.” 
Root, who was Cook’s vice-captain, takes over as Test skipper ahead of England’s one-day series against the West Indies. Alastair Cook and Joe Root after England won the Ashes back in 2015. Source: Getty Images 
His first Test in charge will come against South Africa at Lord’s in July, which will be the first of a four-match series. A three-match home series against the West Indies follows before England’s greatest challenge, an away Ashes series against Australia, begins at the Gabba. in November. 
Root said he was “privileged, humbled and very excited” to take on the new role. 
“We have a very good group of players and I’m looking forward to leading them out in the summer, building on Alastair’s achievements and making the most of our talents in the years ahead,” Root said. 
“The senior guys in the changing room play a very influential role and whilst there’s a natural progression for me it’s a huge support to know that they are there to help and advise.” 
Root has developed into one of the world’s best batsmen since making his debut in December 2012. With 4,594 runs at an average of 52.80 and 11 centuries to his name, he currently sits third in the ICC rankings for Test batsmen. 
Director of England Cricket Andrew Strauss said selectors undertook a proper process to pick a new skipper and that he was delighted Root accepted the role immediately. England's Joe Root averages over 52 at Test level. Source: AFP 
“Joe has shown a number of admirable qualities in his Test career so far,” Strauss said. 
“Making his debut in 2012 at the age of 21 and going on to establish himself as one of the premier batsmen in all forms of the game in such a short period of time demonstrates his drive, determination, cricketing intelligence and an ability to learn that will serve him well in his new role. 
“He is universally respected by his team mates, passionate about driving the Test team forward and extremely excited about the prospect of leading his country.” 
Cook led England for four-and-half years but oversaw his side falter towards the back-end of his tenure, drawing two of their last three series and suffering a 4-0 drubbing in India. 
Cook, whose highlights included two Ashes victories at home in 2013 and 2015 and a first away series victory in India for 28 years in 2012, said it had been a “huge honour” to captain his country.
